chapterDescription: User data to bytes, bytes to disks, retention policies, replication

problems.question: You store 1KB per user action. Users average 20 actions/day. You have 1 million DAU. How much new storage per day?
problems.explanation: 1KB × 20 actions × 1M users = 20 billion bytes = 20 GB per day.
problems.detailedExplanation: 1KB × 20 actions × 1M users = 20 billion bytes = 20 GB per day. Storage estimates should separate raw data, replication factor, index/metadata overhead, and retention window. This framing helps you move from a single number to a defendable capacity plan.

problems.question: A video platform stores 100 hours of new video daily at 1080p (3 GB/hour). Which are true?
problems.detailedExplanation: 100×3=300GB/day, 300×365=109.5TB/year, 300×30=9TB for 30 days. Bandwidth sizing should start with clean unit conversions (bits vs bytes and per-second rates), then include peak multipliers and protocol overhead. That keeps transfer and egress estimates realistic under production traffic.

stages.question: Your service logs 500 bytes per request at 1,000 QPS. Daily log volume?
stages.detailedExplanation: 500 × 1000 × 86400 = 43.2 billion bytes = 43.2 GB. Load estimates should separate average QPS from peak QPS and then map both to per-instance throughput limits. This makes scaling triggers and headroom decisions explicit.
